title: Man wins legal battle against Flybe over 'penal' £50 excess baggage charge
text:

A man has won a ‘David and Goliath’ legal battle against Flybe over a 'penal' £50 excess baggage charge.

Declan Gormley took the airline to the small claims court over a baggage charge on his return flight from Aberdeen to Belfast.

He claimed the excess baggage charge policy was "arbitrary, inconsistent" and "more than anything, penal".

Speaking to Radio Ulster, he said: "I would say in the last 12 months alone I probably would have had eight to 10 flights with Flybe using exactly the same bag that I turned up at Belfast airport on the 19th April with."

Yet Mr Gormley was “never charged” and said they “never indicated they had any concerns” and “never challenged” him.

As a result David said he was quite confident his bag “would be found to be compliant, which it was” when airline staff asked him to put it in the measuring crate, reports Belfast Live.

(Image: Getty)

“That’s the important part of this story,” he continued.

“Flying out of Belfast, Flybe staff asked to check the bag. They put it into their sizer. I flew to Aberdeen with the bag, everything was fine.

“Four days later I was returning and stopped at the gate at Aberdeen airport - and I suppose one of the most crucial differences is not by Flybe staff - but by ground staff at Aberdeen airport using a sizer which wasn’t identified as a Flybe sizer.

“They determined that the bag wasn’t complaint and to get on the flight, I had to pay them £50. Let’s just say I was not happy, particularly as the bag still had the compliance sticker from the flight from four days earlier.”

After a phone call to Flybe’s Exeter office and 10 emails without resolution, Mr Gormley decided to take the airline to the small claims court as he felt that whatever his narrative the airline just gave “another reason to reject it”.

“The whole charge is arbitrary, it’s inconsistent, it’s open to personal interpretation and more than anything it’s penal - £50 to take a bag!” he added.

“The overriding issue is that the starting position for all these organisations is to say ‘no’ and keep saying ‘no’ because they do probably work on the basis that you are just going to go away.

But he didn’t, and after paying £37 to go to the small claims court “which is a very straight forward process” he went to court, where he disputed the claim he “just got lucky” with his bag on the other flights.

Luckily for him the judge agreed.

“My objection is not that they have a policy about the size of their bags, my objection is the application of how it is interpreted... and is open to mistakes. I don’t accept that I got lucky - the people in Aberdeen got it wrong,” he added.

The judge ruled in Declan’s favour and Flybe were told to pay back his £50 plus his £37 court fee.

Now he hopes the case will make the airline think about their baggage policy as “it is clearly not being applied in a fair manner”.

A spokesperson for the airline said: “Flybe can confirm that it has received and is complying with the NI court and tribunal service ruling dated 10 Oct 2019.

“The airline continues to have a generous hand baggage allowance, which since 2016, allows passengers to take on board 2 pieces of cabin baggage. This includes 1 item that does not exceed 55 x 35 x 20cm, and one smaller additional piece such as a handbag or laptop case. Any hand baggage which exceeds these stated dimensions is charged as highlighted to customers during the booking process and again in all pre-flight communications. All information can be found on Flybe website .

“Flybe works closely with its ground handling team to regularly check that its hand baggage policy is being properly and consistently adhered to and applied.”
description: Declan Gormley took the airline to the small claims court over the baggage charge on his return flight from Aberdeen to Belfast
